awd_titl_txt: Selective Catalytic [3+n]-Cycloaddition Reactions with Vinyldiazo Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Division of Chemistry is supporting the research of Professor Michael P. Doyle of the University of Texas at San Antonio. Professor Doyle is developing a class of reactions known as "cycloadditions" that form rings of atoms. These rings are the building blocks of many important compounds, including precursors to biologically active molecules, pharmaceutical drugs, and materials. Professor Doyle has designed chemical systems that are capable of controlling the 3-dimensional shape of the products, a feature that is crucial to the synthesis of molecules of medicinal importance. In addition, some of the these cycloaddition reactions use earth-abundant metals to speed up the reaction. This project provides a training and preparation for the next generation of diverse researchers in the chemical sciences. Undergraduate and graduate students working on this project gain expertise in modern synthetic methods and laboratory techniques while being exposed to an intellectually stimulating and challenging environment that will prepare them for future careers in STEM fields.

The cost-effective preparation of complex chiral molecules is directly dependent on the availability of sustainable synthetic methodologies. In this project, Professor Doyle is advancing the discovery and development of catalytic (3+n)-cycloaddition reactions where n=1, 2, or 3, for the synthesis of carbocyclic and heterocyclic compounds. He and his team are using a metal-stabilized three-carbon vinylcarbene that is derived either from a vinyldiazo compound, or a donor-acceptor cyclopropane, to selectively form products containing 4 to 6-membered rings and up to two heteroatoms. Stereoselectivity in these cycloaddition reactions is imparted via chiral ligands, which restrict the approach of a reactant to one side of the vinylcarbene, providing enantiomeric ratios as high as 99:1. The use of earth-abundant copper catalysts, and the use of cyclopropenes as vinylcarbene sources are also actively pursued. There is also a strong commitment to engaging a diverse group of students to carry out this research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Award from the National Science Foundation for “Selective Catalytic [3+n]-Cycloaddition Reactions with Vinyldiazo Compounds” has met its objectives and gone beyond expectations in its discoveries. In particular, with this funding from the NSF we have been able to further extend the scope of [3+n]-cycloaddition reactions to the synthesis of carbocyclic and heterocyclic organic compounds, demonstrate the alternative uses of chiral copper catalysts as alternatives to the much more expensive dirhodium catalysts, and to show for the first time the uses of a simple Brønsted acid, triflimide, as a catalyst for complex cycloaddition reactions with vinyldiazo compounds.

As an example of the discoveries made under this award, during the course of our investigations of catalytic asymmetric cycloaddition reactions, we discovered a nucleophilic ring opening reaction that couples medicinally relevant chemicals to analogues of beta-lactams that were previously unavailable. Coupling reactions of amines and alcohols are of central importance for applications in chemistry and biology. These transformations typically involve the use of a reagent, activated as an electrophile, onto which nucleophile coupling results in the formation of a carbon-nitrogen or a carbon-oxygen bond. Several promising reagents and procedures have been developed to achieve these bond forming processes in high yields with excellent stereocontrol, but few offer direct coupling without the intervention of a catalyst. We discovered the first synthesis of novel chiral donor−acceptor azetines by highly enantioselective [3+1]-cycloaddition of enoldiazoacetates with aza−ylides and their selective coupling with nitrogen and oxygen nucleophiles via 3-azetidinones to form amino acid derivatives. The overall process is general for a broad spectrum of nucleophiles, has a high degree of electronic and steric selectivity, and retains the enantiopurity of the original azetine. The mild reaction conditions, high enantiocontrol, broad scope of nucleophiles for the ring opening of donor-acceptor azetines, and ability to perform the reaction in aqueous media demonstrated in this work portray a process that will have wide applications. 

And from this discovery flows another research direction – this one by adding hydrogen across the carbon-carbon double bond of the chiral donor−acceptor azetine, mentioned above, a new compound (an azetidine-2-carboxylic acid derivative) is formed that is resistant to ring opening. Chiral azetidine-2-carboxylic acid, the first known example of naturally occurring azetidines, and their derivatives are structural units of several natural products and pharmacologically important compounds. Various methods have been used for their preparation, but all of them are multistep syntheses. We have discovered the first highly enantioselective synthesis of azetine-2-carboxylates and their stereoselective hydrogenation to form tetrasubstituted azetidine derivatives having three chiral centers, all of which having substituents that are cis to each other.

In the development of research that is at the state-of-the-art, the single most important facilitator is having the financial resources to hire the personnel, obtain the instrumentation, and have the supply of chemicals and equipment to carry out research in a timely and productive manner.  A total of two graduate students, four postdoctoral associates, one visiting scientist, one high school chemistry teacher, and sixteen undergraduate students have benefited from this award.  Three of the postdoctoral associates have entered or accepted offers to tenure-track faculty appointments, and three of the undergraduate students have entered graduate school in the chemical sciences. Others have entered the health professions or chemical industry.

Modified by: Michael P Doyle
